choices.A: The import task succeeds, and all properties are imported.
choices.D: The import task succeeds, but only secure properties are not imported.
choices.B: The import task prompts the user for the AES passphrase.

questions.question_text: Which result is true if you export a configuration backup with AES encryption enabled, disable the AES encryption policy on the APIC, and then try to reimport the previously exported configuration file?

discussion.content:
Answer: A
When the Enable Encryption check box is unchecked (off), encryption is disabled and all exported configurations (exports) are missing the secure fields (such as passwords and certificates). When this box is checked (on), encryption is enabled and all exports show the secure fields.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/kb/b_KB_Using_Import_Export_to_Recover_Config_States.html#task_C1B7BF7971E14C36B6861D21B8D136DB

questions.question_text: Which two statements about connecting spines to the Inter-Site Network are true? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Spine to ISN links can be configured with OSPF or static routes.
choices.E: Sites must have two or more spines connected to the ISN.
choices.B: Spine-facing interfaces on the ISN must be configured using subinterface VLAN 4.
choices.D: All spines in a site must be EX or later HW.
choices.A: Only spines connecting to the ISN must be EX or later HW.

discussion.content: and This name-space translation function should be performed at line rate to avoid negatively affecting the performance of intersite communication. To achieve this, you must use specific hardware for the spine nodes deployed in the Cisco ACI Multi-Site architecture: only the Cisco NexusÂ® EX platform (and newer) generation of spine switches are supported in a Multi-Site deployment.
yes, spine to ISN always tagged with VLAN 4

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. ITD is configured as shown on a Cisco Nexus 7000 switch. Why is ping address still not working?

choices.D: VIP must be from the same subnet as the ingress interface.
choices.A: Fail actions is set to the wrong mode.
choices.C: To ping, you must add a probe to the device group.

discussion.content:
B is correct
http://cisco.lookbookhq.com/c/multipod-config-guide
Text from source: Configuring Cisco APIC for a Multipod setup in a Multipod setup, the configuration of the APIC clusters should be specific to the pod to which they belong. Because the Tunnel Endpoint (TEP) pool for each pod must be unique, each pod has its own TEP address pool. This setup enables the IPN routers between the pods to communicate.

Not sure about this (B).
Do APICs run TEPs ? I thought this is for the Leafs only. I think C is also valid.

questions.question_text: Which statement about multipod setup is true?

choices.D: Pod TEP subnet pools must be the same size.
choices.B: APICs configured in Pod-2 are assigned a TEP address from the Pod-2 TEP pool.
choices.A: Pod TEP pools must not be nonoverlapping.
choices.C: APICs can be configured in any Pod.

questions.question_text: Which two options does ITD replace? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Reduced complexities and architecture scaling for alternative features like Web Cache Communication Protocol (WCCP) and policy-based routing
